title: Grubb's Test for Outlier Detection
alpha: alpha: % chance (default 5%), the furthest point from mean identified as outlier
plotShowOutliersChk: Plot to show all points including outlier, if any

help.title: Grubb's Test for Outlier Detection
help.body:
Description
Determine where the extreme point is an outlier in the variable i.e., Y values (no X variable needed)

Grubbs’ Test, also known as the Extreme Studentized Deviate (ESD) method, is a widely used statistical approach for detecting a single outlier in a univariate dataset that follows a normal distribution.

To determine whether the most extreme value in a dataset is significantly different from the others, i.e., whether it is an outlier.

Internal analysis steps:
Calculate the mean (μ) and standard deviation (σ) of the full dataset (including the suspected outlier, unlike the ROUT robust mean approach)
Compute the Grubbs’ test statistic (G also known as Z):

Compute critical value from Grubbs' formula
t_crit = qt(1 - alpha / (2 * n), df = n - 2)
G_crit = ((n - 1) / sqrt(n)) * sqrt(t_crit^2 / (n - 2 + t_crit^2))

Compare the calculated G to a critical value from Grubbs' table (based on sample size and significance level). If G exceeds the critical value, the value is considered a statistically significant outlier.

Iterative Use:
While the classic test detects only one outlier at a time, it can be applied repeatedly to detect multiple outliers — removing one outlier and re-testing on the remaining data.
